awd_titl_txt: Negative Capacitance Phosphorene Tunneling Field Effect Transistors
awd_abstract_narration:
The project intends to study the problem of how to create a transistor that can be switched between its "on" and "off" states with less energy than a conventional transistor. It attempts to break through a fundamental problem in semiconductor chip technology called the "thermionic" limit by combining two mechanisms, tunneling and ferroelectricity, with the emerging field of two-dimensional materials. Such a technology would be a breakthrough in the semiconductor industry leading to smaller computer chips that could perform more functions, and be more easily integrated into mobile and internet-of-things applications. The project will be an ideal training ground for graduate students, as they will simultaneously be able to work on a problem of vital importance to the semiconductor industry, while at the same time, explore many fundamental aspects of quantum mechanics, material science and device physics. Aspects of this work will also be utilized in an undergraduate semiconductor device class, where the results provide an ideal example of a device that combines several "end-of-the-roadmap" concepts. Finally, the results from this project will be incorporated into a summer school outreach program at the University of Minnesota and be utilized for K-12 outreach activities such as in-class demonstrations and interactive activities that can generate excitement about engineering and scientific careers in general.

The goal of the proposed research is to design, fabricate, characterize and analyze the properties of a novel steep-subthreshold slope negative capacitance tunneling field-effect transistor made using the two-dimensional nanomaterial, phosphorene. The device combines two mechanisms: Fermi-function filtering and negative capacitance gate dielectrics to create a device capable of extremely sharp turn-off behavior that is well below the thermionic limit of 60 millivolts per decade. The device further utilizes phosphorene as the channel material, which is an ideal material for tunneling transistors due to its narrow band gap and anisotropic effective mass. The research scope and methods include the development of techniques to create controlled heterostructures in phosphorene with monolayer precision, study of the orientation-dependence of band-to-band tunneling in phosphorene pn junctions, investigation of ferroelectric material deposition and interface quality with phosphorene, fabrication of characterization of the novel steep-subthreshold slope device, and development of a predictive model of the device performance. The intellectual significance of the proposed work is that it addresses key technical challenges associated with two-dimensional semiconductors and ferroelectric materials and answers fundamental questions about the ultimate limits of low-energy transistor operation, thereby tackling one of the most pressing challenges facing the semiconductor device community.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to explore the realization of a novel transistor that combines two effects that can allow the device to switch between "ON" and "OFF" states with less voltage than a conventional metal-oxide-semiconductor field-effect transistor (MOSFET). These two effects are (1) gate modulation of band-to-band tunneling using a so-called tunneling field-effect transistor (TFET), and (2) negative capacitance induced by ferroelectric gating. The project further had as its goal to realize this device using phosphorene, a promising two-dimensional (2D) material that is ideally suited for use in TFETs.  The achievements of the project have been detailed in the report below:

In the first year of the project, the primary finding was that the mechanism in phosphorene TFETs that led to non-ideal behavior was identified. Temperature-dependent analysis showed that these devices had excess electrical current due to so-called defects that can trap electrons and also lead to excess current, thus not allowing observation of the expected sharp switching behavior. In this first year, an initial process for deposition and characterization of ferroelectric zirconium-doped hafnium oxide was also developed.

In the second program year, an additional property of phosphorene, its crystal asymmetry, was used to enhance the properties of TFETs. To demonstrate this concept, an L-shaped TFET was fabricated and its operation demonstrated, and this device showed improved ON-OFF switching behavior compared to devices fabricated using a conventional design. In particular, the side of the device where current is injected (the source) was fabricated using one orientation of phosphorene, while the side of the device where the current is collected (the drain) was fabricated using an orientation rotated 90 degrees from the source. In this way, the ON-state current was enhanced while the OFF-state current was decreased, a novel use of crystal asymmetry to improve TFET performance.

In the third program year, extensive work to investigate black arsenic as an alternative to phosphorene for TFET applications was undertaken. The work in this year showed that oxygen-induced degradation in black arsenic under atmospheric conditions is much less than phosphorene (which degrades within hours of exposure to the air). Extensive investigation of the transport properties of black arsenic were also performed. The temperature- and thickness-dependence of the mobility for electron and holes was investigated and simple analog and digital circuit operation was demonstrated. The results suggest that black arsenic is an interesting candidate material for use in TFETs.

In the final year of the project, a novel property of black arsenic was discovered which could lead to a completely new method of fabricating heterostructures in 2D materials. It was found that evaporated metal onto black arsenic forms a distinct crystalline intermetallic compound layer. In the case of Ni, the intermetallic layer was found to be Ni11As8, while for Cr and Ti, these layers were CrAs and a-Ti3As, respectively. Important learning on the properties of black arsenic-phosphorus alloys and ultra-thin ferroelectric hafnium oxide layers was also developed.

The broader impacts of this work were that it provided new knowledge on a range of other new device concepts, including analog / RF devices, memories and devices that could be used in machine learning applications. Fundamental new materials discoveries were also made, and the formation of crystalline Ni-As intermetallic layers could have several important implications for semiconductor devices as it could provide a new pathway for engineering lateral semiconducting heterostructures and self-aligned contacts with two-dimensional materials. Finally, this work produced results that have been incorporated into the undergraduate education curriculum at the University of Minnesota and contributed to the professional development of graduate students and post-doctoral researchers.
